sessions.name: Chris Stephenson
sessions.bio_html: Wrote his first operating system, in assembler language, for IBM in 1967. Built Turkey's first university Department of Computer Science (now closed). Likes functional programming and writing the tests before writing the program.
sessions.speech_title: Keynote : “Why our future is in our past?”
sessions.speech_detail_html:
Is there any field of human activity where theory is translated into practice more slowly than in the field of programming?

If this process was as slow for computer hardware as it is for software, computers would still occupy whole rooms.

A few examples of things we need to learn from the past.

sessions.name: Mattt Thompson
sessions.title: Mobile Lead at Heroku
sessions.bio_html: Mobile Lead at Heroku, and the creator & maintainer of AFNetworking and other popular open-source projects, including Postgres.app, Helios, & Nomad. He also writes about obscure & overlooked parts of Cocoa on NSHipster.
sessions.speech_title: Building Next-Generation iOS Apps with AFNetworking 2.0
sessions.speech_detail_html: AFNetworking is a delightful open source Objective-C framework for communicating between the client and server. Find out how it's recent 2.0 release can be used to build next-generation iOS 7 apps with real-time functionality, offline support, and background capabilities.

sessions.name: Sinan Yaşar
sessions.title: UI/UX General at Koding.com
sessions.bio_html: Co-Founder and UI General of Koding.com platform. He is also UX Engineer and developer at Koding.com
sessions.speech_title: Why I had to write a client side framework for Koding?
sessions.speech_detail_html:
I am going to talk about how web applications are written today and how javascript frameworks (will eventually) change them.

We're going to cover how different javascript frameworks handle some problems such as templating, partials, mustaches, event binding, modularity etc. and how we approached them. Why we didn't pick the strict MVC rules but solved them more organically. Why we don't like dealing with html/css.

And finally why I had to start writing another one since there were some, and why it is written in coffeescript rather than javascript.

sessions.name: Blake Mizerany
sessions.title: Freelance Engineer
sessions.bio_html: Creator of Ruby web framework Sinatra. He worked as Researcher, Developer and Distributed Systems Architect at Heroku. Ruby, Erlang and C programmer.
sessions.speech_detail_html: If you don't learn Go in the next year, you'll be one more year behind what is now *the* way to quickly build manageable, simple, fast, and reliable systems. This talk will explain why.

sessions.name: Andrew Gerrand
sessions.title: Software Engineer at Google
sessions.bio_html: We works at Google Sydney on the Go Programming Language.
sessions.speech_detail_html:
Go is a general-purpose language that bridges the gap between efficient statically typed languages and productive dynamic language. But it’s not just the language that makes Go special. Go has a broad and consistent standard library and powerful but simple tools.

This talk gives a brief introduction to Go, followed by live coding of a real program to demonstrate the power, scope, and simplicity of the Go programming environment.

sessions.name: Cihan Okyay
sessions.title: Software Developer at Koding.com
sessions.bio_html: He works at Koding.com as software developer.
sessions.speech_title: Using Vagrant as a Development Environment
sessions.speech_detail_html:
Vagrant is a tool for building complete development environments. Some points to present:

  • What is Vagrant ?
  • How does it work ?
  • How to configure a box ? (Salt Stack provision or shell scripts)

sessions.name: Mark Bates
sessions.title: Architect at Meta42 Labs
sessions.bio_html: Founder and chief architect of the Meta42 Labs. In 2009 Mark’s first book, “Distributed Programming with Ruby”, was published by Addison-Wesley. In 2012 Addison-Wesley published Mark’s second book, “Programming in CoffeeScript”.
sessions.speech_detail_html: The world of JavaScript client-side frameworks is overflowing with contenders vying for the crown, but which one do you choose for your next project? Which one has what it takes? In this talk we’ll look at the “Big 3”, AngularJS, Ember.js, and Backbone.js. We’ll compare them head to head, toe to toe. We’ll look at the pros and cons of each one. How do they handle form bindings? Talking to APIs? Code organization? Routing? Etc? Who’ll come out victorious in this battle of the JavaScript frameworks, or will we all just come out bloodied and bruised on the other side? Guess we’ll find out!

sessions.name: Taylan Pinçe
sessions.title: Tech Lead at Hipo
sessions.bio_html: He is passionate about good design and development methodologies, both on the client side, and behind the curtains. He leads the talented web and mobile development team at Hipo.
sessions.speech_title: Beyond REST: Mobile Applications and Custom API Protocols
sessions.speech_detail_html: Most mobile applications are built on a RESTful API layer that uses standard HTTP for communicating back and forth. In this talk we will take a look at the principles of REST and how to best integrate them in a mobile context. But then we will take this topic further and explore what kind of specialized API layers can be used with mobile apps, such as custom TCP-based protocols and other purpose-built socket connections that offer more flexibility and live update features.

sessions.name: Joshua Ballanco
sessions.title: Chief Scientist at Burnside Digital
sessions.bio_html: He is a core developer of MacRuby and Rubymotion. He lives in Ankara/Turkey. He works at Burnside Digital.
sessions.speech_title: Sure, I could learn Objective-C, but...
sessions.speech_detail_html: If you've heard of RubyMotion, chances are that you've also heard people tell you to “just learn Objective-C”. In this talk, we'll look at how RubyMotion is so much more than a way to write iOS apps in another language. Using all the strengths of Ruby, we'll see how RubyMotion can make your code cleaner, easier to read, and more efficient.

sessions.name: Barış Daylık
sessions.title: CTO at VNGRS
sessions.bio_html: He works at VNGRS as Chief Technology Officer.
sessions.speech_detail_html: Developers have big challenges today. Multi-core and multi-node deployments are becoming de facto standart, demand for distributed and parallel applications is ever increasing. Users are expecting faster responses and high-availability, downtimes won't be forgiven. To overcome those challenges, applications should be event-driven, easily scalable, much more responsive, and fault-tolerant from ground up, thus
. This talk will introduce you the reactive principles.
